document.docAuthor: Orr, Michael C., Pitts, James P. & Griswold, Terry
document.masterDocTitle: Revision of the bee group Anthophora (Micranthophora) (Hymenoptera: Apidae), with notes on potential conservation concerns and a molecular phylogeny of the genus

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of the bee group Anthophora (Micranthophora) (Hymenoptera: Apidae), with notes on potential conservation concerns and a molecular phylogeny of the genus

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Anthophora maculifrons Cresson, 1879: 210
( lectotype ( Cresson, 1916 ): ♀ ; Nevada , USA ; coll. Morrison; ANSP, 2274).

subSubSection.paragraph: Female similar to male, except: Head: Mandible with inferior tooth ridge-like but expanded, slightly angled off main blade ( Fig. 41B ). Labral rim rounded; fully maculated. Clypeal maculation similarly variable but typically stronger ( Fig. 41B ). Scape immaculate. Mesosoma: Midtibial spur apically curved; tan to orange. Basitibial plate circular distally, teardropped overall. Metasoma: T1 covered in appressed setae; T2–T4 with appressed setal bands of variable thickness, sometimes only absent in very narrow basal zones, usually undulate; T5 with extensive appressed setae. T4 impunctate rim of short to almost moderate length medially, distinct but weak. Anal fimbria triangular or vaguely so, filling around third to under half of T5 length medially. Pubescence: See Fig. 46B . Hindbasitarsal brush dark brown; anal fimbria usually orangish, sometimes invaded posteriorly by brown; S5 with dark apicomedially, hidden by light.

Distribution. See Fig. 19 . Present in: USA : California , Utah , Idaho , Oregon , Nevada , Wyoming , Colorado , Arizona , likely Montana , possibly Washington ; Mexico : possibly Baja California Norte. Found throughout much of west, montane in hotter areas, occupying broader range of environments in colder areas. Ecoregional habitance is as follows, based on 352 specimen records: 16 ecoregions total: Mojave Desert (116=33%), Great Basin shrub steppe (65=18.5%), Colorado Plateau shrublands (41=11.6%), Eastern Cascades forests (27=7.7%), Sierra Nevada forests (26=7.4%), Wyoming Basin shrub steppe (23=6.5%), Snake-Columbia shrub steppe (17=4.8%), Wasatch and Uinta montane forests (12=3.4%), Colorado Rockies forests (8=2.3%), California montane chaparral and woodlands (5=1.4%), Blue Mountains forests (5=1.4%), Arizona Mountains forests (2≤1%), Central and Southern Cascades forests (2≤1%), Sonoran Desert (1≤1%), California coastal sage and chaparral (1≤1%), Klamath- Siskiyou forests (1≤1%).
Phenology. Recorded from April–October, almost exclusively late summer to fall, most common in August– September. Likely univoltine, possibly emerging opportunistically on rare occasions.

Floral specialization. Reported as a specialist on
Chrysothamnus
( Asteraceae ) ( Moldenke & Neff 1974 ). Appears mostly true; known associations suggest specialization on
Chrysothamnus
and
Ericameria
as well as other fall flowering shrubs in Asteraceae . Primary recorded visits by 131 females include: Family Asteraceae (98%); Genus
Ericameria
(38%),
Chrysothamnus
(35%),
Gutierrezia
(23%); Species
Ericameria nauseosa
(34%). 190 total floral records from three families include:
Asteraceae
( 58 ♂ 128 ♀ ):
Aster
sp. 1 ♀ ,
Centaurea
sp. 1 ♂ ,
Chrysothamnus nauseosus
1 ♀ ,
Chrysothamnus
sp. 14 ♂ 41 ♀ ,
Chrysothamnus viscidiflorus
5 ♂ 3 ♀ ,
Ericameria nauseosa
25 ♂ 48 ♀ ,
Ericameria
sp. 6 ♂ 2 ♀ ,
Grindelia squarrosa
1 ♂ ,
Gutierrezia microcephala
12 ♀ ,
Gutierrezia sarothrae
1 ♂ 11 ♀ ,
Gutierrezia
sp. 1 ♂ 8 ♀ ,
Helianthus
sp. 1 ♂ ,
Machaeranthera canescens
1 ♀ ,
Machaeranthera pinnatifida
1 ♂ ,
Vanclevea stylosa
2 ♂ ,
Orobanchaceae
( 1 ♀ ):
Cordylanthus
sp. 1 ♀ ,
Polygonaceae
( 1 ♂ 2 ♀ ):
Eriogonum effusum
1 ♀ ,
Eriogonum nummulare
1 ♀ ,
Eriogonum trichopes
1 ♂ .

Anthophora maculifrons
